Toilet users in Austria need not be concerned about this problem because our toilets are designed differently.  Our toilets have a flat shelf built into the bowl design, so there is no standing water other than what is in the very front of the toilet where the water is flushed out and down the pipes. What happens when one poos is that the excrement falls onto this ceramic shelf where there is no water, and then once the toilet is flushed, it is pushed to the front of the toilet bowl, and down the pipe. Our toilets also usually have two levers: one that uses less water when one pees, and the other which uses more water when necessary. If you do an image search for toilets in Austria, you will see a more graphic illustration of what I mean.

I get splashback that can’t be prevented by using this method. Allow me to explain:

The blunt leading end goes directly down the hole, but the overall length is often triple or quadruple the distance from “source” to water surface. So the leading end plants itself firm and when the trailing tapered end is formed and clipped off, it sets into motion much like a tree being chopped down, falling forward (often grazing the rear seam of the scrotal sac on its way down), and landing in the front of the bowl, usually poking up out the top of the water’s surface. As it makes this fall forward, the water is pushed out of the way and splashes as it travels up the front of the bowl and hits the underside of the rim. Subsequent residual leftovers fall onto the forearm-sized tree, but since they end up partially out of the water, they act as a wedge, forcing the water to the sides.

Destin,

I've been using the same anti-splash technology myself for many years, however I'm not convinced by your conclusion that the solution is due to a change in surface tension.
From many thousands of "experimental observations", I'm convinced that the real reason is that the TP introduces just enough "drag" to slow the "projectile's" entry into the water, thus reducing the length of the void, and disrupting the slapback effect.
( I refer to this effect as: "returdation". ;-))

In your video, you can see from the "above" shots how the entire length of TP upon impact is pulled towards the point of impact, which introduces friction across the srface of the water, and thus "returding" the entry velocity just enough to make a difference.
I suggest a more extensive experiment is required to determine whether the result is due to "change in surface tension", as you suppose, or is due to "returdation" effects as I suggest (or a combination of both).
Perhaps by substituting a surfactant such as detergent for the TP, in order to change the surface tension without introducing "returdation", you can flush out which theory is correct.

Surface tension is only applicable to liquids. Gases are not dense enough to adhere to the same principles,but the physical phenomenon of cavity appearance upon entry of an obj is still relevant. However the refilling of this cavity would be nowhere near as dramatic or violent as is the case with water as it will rely only on diffusion and aerodynamic turbulence caused by the aircraft. Also, these reactions will be further dulled by the gradient properties of the atmospheric border with space ^^
